items.title: Scientists race to drill into 'Doomsday Glacier' as weather threatens mission

featured_image.name: What happens when the Thwaites Glacier in Antarctica, the so ...

items.description:
Hundreds of previously undetected earthquakes are rattling Antarctica's Thwaites Glacier, while an international team of scientists aboard a Korean icebreaker struggles against harsh weather to drill into the massive ice sheet that could reshape the world's coastlines if it collapses.

A study published in Geophysical Research Letters by seismologist Thanh-Son Phạm of the Australian National University detected 362 glacial earthquakes in West Antarctica between 2010 and 2023, with 245 of them occurring at Thwaites—nicknamed the "Doomsday Glacier" because its collapse could trigger catastrophic sea level rise. The earthquakes, caused by massive icebergs capsizing as they calve from the glacier, were largely missed by global seismic networks due to their low-frequency waves.[1][2][3][4]

"It is a lot less stable and has been hit by hundreds of iceberg earthquakes," Phạm told Gizmodo, noting that the most prolific period of seismic activity between 2018 and 2020 coincided with an accelerated flow of the glacier's ice tongue toward the sea.[4][1]

items.title: Trump cancels Iran talks, warns protesters 'help is on its way'

featured_image.name: Trump cancel meetings with Iranian officials and tells protesters ...

items.description:
The death toll from Iran's largest anti-government protests in decades climbed to an estimated 2,000 on Tuesday, according to the U.S.-based Human Rights Activists News Agency (HRANA), as President Donald Trump canceled diplomatic talks with Tehran and warned protesters that "help is on its way."[1][2][3]

The casualty figures dwarf those from any previous unrest in the Islamic Republic since the 1979 revolution. HRANA reported that 1,847 protesters, 135 security personnel, and nine children were among the dead, with more than 16,700 people detained.[1] An Iranian official separately confirmed to Reuters that approximately 2,000 people have been killed.[4][5]

items.title: Trump vows US will control Greenland 'one way or the other'

featured_image.name: Trump says he still wants to buy Greenland, suggests Canada ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump has intensified his campaign to acquire Greenland, asserting that the United States will take action "one way or the other" to control the Arctic territory. The renewed push has sparked a diplomatic row with NATO ally Denmark and drawn skepticism from experts who say the island's mineral wealth remains largely inaccessible despite estimates of 1.5 million tons of rare earth elements.[1][2]

"We are going to do something on Greenland whether they like it or not," Trump said Friday, arguing that U.S. control is necessary to prevent Russia or China from establishing a foothold in the region. The president has warned that without American intervention, Greenland would see "Chinese destroyers and submarines all over the place"—claims that Nordic intelligence officials and defense analysts have dismissed as unfounded.[3][4][1]

items.title: U.S. files warrants to seize dozens more Venezuela oil tankers

featured_image.name: U.S. seizes Russian-flagged oil tanker linked to Venezuela after ...

items.description:
The U.S. government has filed court warrants to seize dozens more tankers linked to the Venezuelan oil trade, four sources told Reuters, as Washington moves to consolidate control over oil shipments in and out of the South American country following the capture of President Nicolás Maduro earlier this month.[1][2]

The U.S. military and Coast Guard have already seized five vessels in recent weeks in international waters that were either carrying Venezuelan crude or had done so in the past. The latest push to obtain additional warrants signals an expansion of the Trump administration's campaign to choke off Venezuela's oil exports and assert authority over a maritime trade it says is riddled with sanctions evaders.

items.title: Japan launches first deep-sea mission to mine rare earths

featured_image.name: Japan prepares to mine its deep seabed by decade's end

items.description: Japan has embarked on a historic deep-sea expedition to secure its own supply of rare earth minerals, deploying the scientific drilling vessel Chikyu on Monday from Shimizu Port in Shizuoka toward waters near Minamitori Island, a remote coral atoll approximately 1,900 kilometers southeast of Tokyo. The month-long mission represents the world's first attempt to continuously extract rare earth-rich mud from a depth of 6,000 meters below the ocean surface—a technological feat that could reshape Japan's approach to sourcing materials critical to electric vehicles, electronics, and defense systems.[1][2][3][4]

items.title: Space station research yields new weapon against drug-resistant infections

featured_image.name: Scientists Watched Viruses Attack Bacteria in Space. Things ...

items.description:
Viruses sent to the International Space Station evolved in unexpected ways that could help scientists develop new treatments for antibiotic-resistant infections on Earth, according to research published Tuesday in the journal PLOS Biology.

Researchers at the University of Wisconsin-Madison found that microgravity aboard the ISS fundamentally reshapes how bacteriophages—viruses that infect bacteria—interact with their hosts. The findings suggest that space-based research could unlock new approaches to combating drug-resistant pathogens that threaten public health worldwide.

items.title: Greenland's leader rejects Trump: 'We choose Denmark'

featured_image.name: We choose Denmark' over the US, Greenland's Prime Minister ...

items.description:
Greenland's Prime Minister Jens-Frederik Nielsen categorically rejected U.S. President Donald Trump's push to acquire the Arctic territory, declaring on Tuesday that Greenland chooses to remain part of Denmark rather than join the United States.

"We are now facing a geopolitical crisis, and if we have to choose between the United States and Denmark here and now, we choose Denmark," Nielsen said at a joint press conference in Copenhagen alongside Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen[1][2]. The announcement marks a direct rebuff to Trump's escalating threats to take control of the strategic Arctic island.

items.title: Major brands mock AI-generated ads as tech giants pour billions into infrastructure

featured_image.name: Nasdaq: Avgo

items.description: As the new year dawns, artificial intelligence stands at a crossroads. Tech giants are pouring hundreds of billions of dollars into AI infrastructure while promising practical consumer applications, even as major brands publicly distance themselves from AI-generated content and investors grow more selective about AI bets.

items.title: Greenland chooses Denmark over US as Trump escalates push

featured_image.name: Greenland PM's message for Trump: 'We choose Denmark ... - CNBC

items.description:
President Donald Trump is intensifying his campaign to bring Greenland under American control, with the White House confirming that all options—including military force—remain on the table. The push comes as prediction market odds for U.S. acquisition of the Arctic territory have roughly doubled over the past year, even as experts warn that Greenland's mineral riches may be largely inaccessible.

"We are going to do something on Greenland whether they like it or not," Trump declared last week, adding that while he would prefer to negotiate, "if that doesn't happen, we will pursue the hard way."[1][2]

items.title: Iran raids homes for Starlink devices as protest crackdown intensifies

featured_image.name: Iran Is Hunting Down Starlink Users to Stop Protest Videos ...

items.description:
Iranian security forces have launched house-to-house searches across Tehran and other cities to seize Starlink satellite dishes, seeking to sever protesters' last remaining link to the outside world as a deadly crackdown enters its third week. The confiscation campaign comes alongside military-grade jamming that has disrupted up to 80% of Starlink traffic in the country since Tehran imposed a near-total internet blackout on January 8[1][2][3].

Over the weekend, authorities in western Tehran began raiding homes to confiscate Starlink equipment, according to Amir Rashidi, director of digital rights and security at the U.S.-based nonprofit Miaan Group. "This is electronic warfare," Rashidi told The Wall Street Journal, noting that operations have been most severe in protest hotspots and during evening gatherings[1][4]. Iranian forces have also deployed drones to patrol rooftops searching for Starlink antennas as part of large-scale confiscation operations[2].

items.title: El-Erian warns AI rally faces headwinds as bubble fears grow

featured_image.name: For the first time in 20 years, AI bubble fears have fund managers ...

items.description:
After three consecutive years of double-digit gains fueled by artificial intelligence enthusiasm, Wall Street is now grappling with mounting warnings that the AI-driven rally may face headwinds in the year ahead.

Mohamed El-Erian, the former co-CIO at PIMCO, issued a stark warning in an op-ed published Monday, cautioning investors that the "AI narrative is unlikely to prove strong enough to continue overshadowing other lingering uncertainties" as 2026 progresses[1][2]. The respected economist pointed to economic inequality, geopolitical turmoil, and fears of overvaluation as factors that could derail what he called a "rational bubble."[1][3]

items.title: U.S. urges Americans to leave Iran as Trump cancels talks and backs protesters

featured_image.name: Protests in Iran January 2026

items.description:
The United States issued an urgent evacuation order for all American citizens in Iran on Sunday as anti-government protests entered their third week, with President Donald Trump canceling diplomatic talks and warning Tehran that "help is on its way" for demonstrators facing a deadly crackdown.

The State Department elevated its travel advisory to the highest level on January 12, telling Americans to "leave Iran now" and not to rely on U.S. government assistance for departure.[1][2][3] With commercial flights suspended until at least Friday and a near-total internet blackout in effect, officials directed citizens to flee overland through Turkey or Armenia.[4]

items.title: China installs world's first 20 MW offshore wind turbine

featured_image.name: World's first 20 MW offshore wind turbine installed in China

items.description:
China Three Gorges Corporation has installed the world's first 20-megawatt offshore wind turbine in the waters off Fujian Province, marking a global milestone in renewable energy technology. The turbine was successfully hoisted and completed on Tuesday in a project that demonstrates China's growing dominance in the offshore wind sector.

The massive turbine, located more than 30 kilometers from the coast of southeast China, features three blades measuring nearly 150 meters in length that reach a height of 174 meters above sea level[1][2][3]. Once connected to the grid, the single unit is expected to generate over 80 million kilowatt-hours of electricity annually—enough to power approximately 44,000 households[1][2].

items.title: Solar panels built to last decades can't be recycled or repaired

featured_image.name: The solar boom has a dirty secret. Here's how to avoid another ...

items.description:
The global solar energy sector faces a potential waste crisis as experts warn that panels installed during the renewable energy surge of the 2000s and 2010s are reaching the end of their lifespan, with current designs making repair and recycling nearly impossible.

According to new analysis published this week by Rabia Charef, Senior Research Associate in Circular Economy and Digitalisation at Lancaster University, the world could face up to 250 million tonnes of solar panel waste by 2050 if the industry fails to adopt new design practices[1][2][3]. The panels that powered the clean energy transition were built to withstand decades of harsh weather but were never designed to be repaired, refurbished, or disassembled.

items.title: Meta cuts 1,000 Reality Labs jobs, shifting focus to AI glasses

featured_image.name: Meta Is Reportedly Laying Off Hundreds of Metaverse Employees This Week

items.description:
Meta Platforms has begun notifying more than 1,000 employees in its Reality Labs division of layoffs, marking a decisive retreat from the virtual reality and metaverse ambitions that once defined the company's future. The cuts, announced Tuesday morning, represent roughly 10% of the 15,000-person division and will disproportionately impact teams working on VR headsets and Horizon Worlds, Meta's VR-based social network[1][2][3].

Chief Technology Officer Andrew Bosworth informed affected employees via an internal memo reviewed by Bloomberg, with resources being redirected toward AI-powered wearables and smartphone features[2][4]. The move signals an acknowledgment that Meta's costly metaverse vision—which prompted CEO Mark Zuckerberg to rename the company from Facebook in 2021—has failed to gain mainstream traction.

items.title: IOC considers rotating Winter Olympics among fixed venues

featured_image.name: Climate change threatens future Winter Olympics venues | CBC ...

items.description: As the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics approach next month, growing evidence shows that climate change is reshaping the geography of where the Winter Games can be held. The International Olympic Committee is now considering rotating the Olympics among a permanent pool of suitable locations and moving events earlier in the season as warming temperatures diminish reliable winter conditions worldwide.

items.title: China urges Canada to break from U.S. ahead of Carney visit

featured_image.name: Canadian prime minister visits China after nearly a decade ...

items.description:
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney arrives in Beijing on Wednesday for a four-day visit, the first by a Canadian leader in nearly a decade, as China's state media ramps up pressure on Ottawa to chart a foreign policy course independent of the United States[1][2][3].

The trip, scheduled for January 14-17, comes as Canada grapples with a trade war with its southern neighbor and the fallout from President Donald Trump's tariffs and repeated suggestions that Canada could become "the 51st state"[3][4]. China sees an opportunity to peel the longtime U.S. ally away from Washington, at least partially, through what Beijing calls "strategic autonomy"[2][5].

items.title: Denmark, Greenland officials to meet Vance, Rubio at White House

featured_image.name: Rubio Says He'll Meet With Danish Officials to Discuss Greenland

items.description:
Foreign ministers from Denmark and Greenland are set to meet US Vice President JD Vance and Secretary of State Marco Rubio at the White House on Wednesday, as President Donald Trump intensifies threats to take control of the Arctic territory "whether they like it or not."[1][2] Danish Foreign Minister Lars Lokke Rasmussen said the meeting was requested to "move this whole discussion into a meeting room where we can look each other in the eye."[1]

Trump has repeatedly framed the acquisition of Greenland as essential for US national security, citing concerns about Russian and Chinese activity in the Arctic. "We don't want Russia or China going to Greenland, which if we don't take Greenland, you can have Russia or China as your next door neighbor," Trump told reporters Friday.[3][4]

items.title: China says sci-fi flying aircraft carrier could become real

featured_image.name: White Emperor: China reveals mysterious jet that could be ...

items.description:
Chinese state media has declared the nation's science fiction-inspired aerospace concepts will become reality, signaling a shift in how Beijing frames its ambitions for air and space dominance. A CCTV military channel broadcast on January 10 repositioned the Nantianmen Project—a futuristic weapons program dating to 2017—from fantasy to attainable technology[1][2].

Military analyst Wang Mingzhi of the PLA Air Force Command College stated on the program that "whether it can be realized is no longer the question; we should ask what will be realized first."[1][3] The comments mark the first official framing of the concepts as genuine development targets rather than educational displays.

items.title: Global markets pause as investors await key US inflation data

featured_image.name: European markets live updates: Stoxx 600, FTSE, CAC, DAX today - CNBC

items.description: Stock markets around the world entered a holding pattern on Tuesday as investors awaited a crucial US consumer inflation report that could shape Federal Reserve policy decisions in the months ahead. While US futures edged lower, Asian equities surged to record highs and European markets traded flat to slightly higher.
